{{tone|date=June 2012}} '''School violence''' encompasses physical violence, including student-on-student fighting and [[corporal punishment]]; [[Psychological abuse|psychological violence]], including verbal abuse; [[sexual violence]], including rape and sexual harassment; many forms of [[bullying]], including [[cyberbullying]]; and carrying weapons in school.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0024/002469/246970e.pdf|title=School Violence and Bullying: Global Status Report|last=UNESCO|first=|publisher=Paris, UNESCO|year=2017|isbn=978-92-3-100197-0|location=|pages=9, 110–111}}</ref> It is widely held to have become a serious problem in recent decades in many countries, especially where weapons such as guns or knives are involved. It includes [[violence]] between school students as well as physical attacks by students on school staff.
==Risk factors==
===Internalizing and externalizing behaviors===
A distinction is made between internalizing and externalizing behavior. Internalizing behaviors reflect withdrawal, inhibition, anxiety, and/or [[depression (mood)|depression]]. Internalizing behavior has been found in some cases of youth violence although in some youth, depression is associated with substance abuse. Because they rarely act out, students with internalizing problems are often overlooked by school personnel.<ref name="Christie">Christie, C.A., Nelson, C.M., & Jolivet, K. (2005). [http://www.edjj.org/focus/prevention/plr.pdf ''Prevention of antisocial and violent behavior in youth: A review of the literature''.] Lexington, KY: University of Kentucky. Retrieved 2009-05-01.</ref> Externalizing behaviors refer to delinquent activities, aggression, and hyperactivity. Unlike internalizing behaviors, externalizing behaviors include, or are directly linked to, violent episodes. Violent behaviors such as punching and kicking are often learned from observing others.<ref>Bandura, A. (1983). Psychological mechanisms of aggression. In R. G. Geen & E. I. Donnerstein (Eds.), ''Aggression: Theoretical and empirical reviews''. New York: Academic. {{ISBN|0-12-278801-X}}</ref><ref name="akers">{{cite journal | last1 = Akers | first1 = R. L. | last2 = Krohn | first2 = M. D. | last3 = Lanza-Kaduce | first3 = L. | last4 = Radosevich | first4 = M. | year = 1979 | title = Social learning and deviant behavior: A specific test of a general theory | url = | journal = American Sociological Review | volume = 44 | issue = 4| pages = 635–655 |pmid = 389120 | doi=10.2307/2094592}}</ref> Just as externalizing behaviors are observed outside of school, such behaviors also observed in schools.<ref name="Christie"/>
===Other individual factors===
A number of other individual factors are associated with higher levels of aggressiveness. Compared to children whose antisocial conduct begins in adolescence, early starters have a worse prognosis in terms of future aggression and other antisocial activities.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1017/S0954579498001734 | last1 = Patterson | first1 = G. R. | last2 = Forgatch | first2 = M. S. | last3 = Yoerger | first3 = K. L. | last4 = Stoolmiller | first4 = M. | year = 1998 | title = Variables that initiate and maintain an early-onset trajectory for juvenile offending | url = | journal = Developmental Psychopathology | volume = 10 | issue = 3| pages = 531–547 }}</ref> Lower IQ is related to higher levels of aggression.<ref name = "Hirschi & Hindelang"/><ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1037/0022-3514.52.1.232 | last1 = Huesmann | first1 = L. R. | last2 = Eron | first2 = L. D. | last3 = Yarmel | first3 = P. W. | year = 1987 | title = Intellectual functioning and aggression | url = | journal = Journal of Personality and Social Psychology | volume = 52 | issue = 1| pages = 232–240 | pmid = 3820075 }}</ref><ref name="Loeber">{{cite journal | last1 = Loeber | first1 = R. | last2 = Farrington | first2 = D. P. | last3 = Stouthamer-Loeber | first3 = M. | last4 = Moffitt | first4 = T. E. | last5 = Caspi | first5 = A.| last6 =Lynam | year = 1998| first6 =Don | title = The development of male offending: Key findings from the first decade of the Pittsburgh Youth Study | url = | journal = Clinical Child and Family Psychology Review | volume = 7 | issue = 4 | pages = 273–297 | doi = 10.1023/A:1013574903810 }}</ref> Other findings indicate that in boys early problematic motor skills, attentional difficulties, and reading problems predict later persistent antisocial conduct.<ref name="Moffitt">{{cite journal | doi = 10.2307/1130972 | last1 = Moffitt | first1 = T. E. | year = 1990 | title = Juvenile delinquency and attention deficit disorder: Boys' developmental trajectories from age 3 to age 15 | jstor = 1130972| journal = Child Development | volume = 61 | issue = 3| pages = 893–910 | pmid = 2364762 }}</ref>
===Home environment=== The home environment is thought to contribute to school violence. The Constitutional Rights Foundation suggests long-term exposure to [[gun]] violence, parental [[alcoholism]], [[domestic violence]], physical abuse of the child, and child sexual abuse teaches children that criminal and violent activities are acceptable.<ref name="CRE">Constitutional Rights Foundation. (1997). [http://www.crf-usa.org/school-violence/causes-of-school-violence.html ''Causes of school violence'']. Retrieved on April 20, 2009.</ref> Harsh parental discipline is associated with higher levels of aggressiveness in youth.<ref name="Sampson"/> There is some evidence indicating that exposure to [[television violence]]<ref>Bushman, B. J., & Huesmann, L. R. (2001). Effects of televised violence on aggression. In D. G. Singer & J. L. Singer (Eds.), ''Handbook of children and the media'' (pp. 223–254). Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage. {{ISBN|0-7619-1954-6}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1177/009365094021004004 | last1 = Paik | first1 = H. | last2 = Comstock | first2 = G. | year = 1994 | title = The effects of television violence on antisocial behavior: A meta-analysis | url = | journal = Communication Research | volume = 21 | issue = 4| pages = 516–546 }}</ref> and, to a lesser extent, violent video games<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1111/1467-9280.00366 | last1 = Anderson | first1 = C. A. | last2 = Bushman | first2 = B. J. | year = 2001 | title = Effects of violent video games on aggressive behavior, aggressive cognition, aggressive affect, physiological arousal, and prosocial behavior: A meta-analytic review of the scientific literature | url = | journal = Psychological Science | volume = 12 | issue = 5| pages = 353–359 | pmid = 11554666 }}</ref> is related to increased aggressiveness in children, which, in turn, may carry over into school.
Straus adduced evidence for the view that exposure to parental [[Corporal punishment in the home|corporal punishment]] increases the risk of aggressive conduct in children and adolescents.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1525/sp.1991.38.2.03a00010 | last1 = Straus | first1 = M. A. | year = 1991 | title = Discipline and deviance: Physical punishment of children and violence and other crime in adulthood | url = | journal = Social Problems | volume = 38 | issue = 2| pages = 133–154 }}</ref> Straus's findings have been contested by Larzelere<ref>Larzelere, R. (1997). [http://people.biola.edu/faculty/paulp/CritiqueStraus.html ''Critique of anti-spanking study'']. Biola University.</ref> and [[Diana Baumrind|Baumrind]].<ref>[http://www.fractaldomains.com/devpsych/baumrind.htm ''Words from Diana Baumrind on corporal punishment'']. (1998).</ref><ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1037/0033-2909.128.4.580 | last1 = Baumrind | first1 = D. | last2 = Larzelere | first2 = R. | last3 = Cowan | first3 = P. | year = 2002 | title = Ordinary physical punishment: Is it harmful? Comment on Gershoff (2002) | url = http://www.apa.org/journals/releases/bul1284580.pdf | format = PDF | journal = Psychological Bulletin | volume = 128 | issue = 4| pages = 580–589 | pmid = 12081082 }}</ref> A [[meta-analysis]] of the vast literature on corporal punishment, however, indicates that corporal punishment is related to poorer outcomes in children and youth.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1037/0033-2909.128.4.539 | last1 = Gershoff | first1 = E. T. | year = 2002a | title = Corporal punishment by parents and associated child behaviors and experiences: A meta-analytic and theoretical review | url = | journal = Psychological Bulletin | volume = 128 | issue = 4| pages = 539–579 | pmid = 12081081 }}</ref> The methodologically soundest studies indicate "positive, moderately sized associations between parental corporal punishment and children’s aggression."<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1037/0033-2909.128.4.602 | last1 = Gershoff | first1 = E. T. | year = 2002b | title = Corporal punishment, physical abuse, and the burden of proof: Reply to Baumrind, Larzelere, and Cowan (2002), Holden (2002), and Parke (2002) | url = | journal = Psychological Bulletin | volume = 128 | issue = 4| pages = 602–611 }}</ref> Gershoff found that the trajectory of mean effect sizes (the size of the effect of corporal punishment on children's problem behavior) was curvilinear with the largest mean effect size in middle school (''M'' = 0.55; on average the mean of corporal punishment group was more than half a standard deviation higher than the mean of the non-punishment group) and slightly smaller effect sizes in grade school (''M'' = 0.43) and high school (''M'' = 0.45).
Gerald Patterson's social interactional model, which involves the mother's application and the child's counterapplication of ''coercive'' behaviors, also explains the development of aggressive conduct in the child.<ref name="Patterson">Patterson, G. (1982). ''Coercive family process''. Eugene, OR: Castalia. {{ISBN|0-916154-02-5}}</ref><ref>Patterson, G. R. (1995). Coercion as a basis for early age of onset for arrest. In J. McCord (Ed.), ''Coercion and punishment in long-term perspectives'' (pp. 81–105). New York: Cambridge University Press.</ref> In this context, coercive behaviors include behaviors that are ordinarily punishing (e.g., whining, yelling, hitting, etc.). Abusive home environments can inhibit the growth of social cognitive skills needed, for example, to understand the intentions of others.<ref name="CRE"/><ref name="Dodge, Pettit">{{cite journal | doi = 10.1037/0021-843X.104.4.632 | last1 = Dodge | first1 = K. A. | last2 = Pettit | first2 = G. S. | last3 = Bates | first3 = J. E. | last4 = Valente | first4 = E. | year = 1995 | title = Social information processing patterns partially mediate the effect of early physical abuse on later conduct problems | url = | journal = Journal of Abnormal Psychology | volume = 104 | issue = 4| pages = 632–643 | pmid = 8530766 }}</ref> Short-term longitudinal evidence is consistent with the view that a lack of social cognitive skills [[Mediation (statistics)|mediates]] the link between harsh parental discipline and aggressive conduct in kindergarten.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.2307/1131558 | last1 = Weiss | first1 = B. | last2 = Dodge | first2 = K. A. | last3 = Bates | first3 = J. E. | last4 = Pettit | first4 = G. S. | year = 1992 | title = Some consequences of early harsh discipline: Child aggression and a maladaptive social information processing style | jstor = 1131558| journal = Child Development | volume = 63 | issue = 6| pages = 1321–1335 | pmid = 1446555 }}</ref> Longer-term, follow-up research with the same children suggests that partial mediating effects last until third and fourth grade.<ref name="Dodge, Pettit"/> Hirschi's (1969) control theory advances the view that children with weak affective ties to parents and school are at increased risk of engaging in delinquent and violent behavior in and out of school.<ref name="Hirschi">Hirschi, T.W. (1969). ''Causes of delinquency''. Berkeley: University of California Press. {{ISBN|0-520-01487-1}}</ref> Hirschi's [[cross-sectional study|cross-sectional]] data from northern California high-school students are largely consistent with this view.<ref name="Hirschi"/> Findings from [[case-control study|case-control]]<ref name="Sampson">Sampson, R., & Laub, J. (1993). ''Crime in the making: Pathways and turning points through life''. Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press. {{ISBN|0-674-17604-9}}</ref> and [[longitudinal study|longitudinal studies]]<ref name="Borowsky">{{cite journal | doi = 10.1367/1539-4409(2002)002<0475:VRAPFA>2.0.CO;2 | last1 = Borowsky | first1 = I. W. | last2 = Ireland | first2 = M. | last3 = Resnick | first3 = M. D. | year = 2002 | title = Violence risk and protective factors among youth held back in school | url = | journal = Ambulatory Pediatrics | volume = 2 | issue = 6| pages = 475–484 | pmid = 12437395 }}</ref><ref name="Wiesner">{{cite journal | doi = 10.1023/B:JOYO.0000037635.06937.13 | last1 = Wiesner | first1 = M. | last2 = Windle | first2 = M. | year = 2004 | title = Assessing covariates of adolescent delinquency trajectories: A latent growth mixture modeling approach | url = | journal = Journal of Youth and Adolescence | volume = 33 | issue = 5| pages = 431–442 }}</ref> are also consistent with this view.
===Neighbourhood environment=== Neighbourhoods and communities provide the context for school violence. Communities with high rates of crime and drug use teach youth the violent behaviors that are carried into schools.<ref name="CRE"/><ref name="Evans">{{cite journal | doi = 10.1037/0003-066X.59.2.77 | last1 = Evans | first1 = G. W. | year = 2004 | title = The environment of childhood poverty | url = | journal = American Psychologist | volume = 59 | issue = 2| pages = 77–92 | pmid = 14992634 }}</ref><ref>Gottfredson, G. D., & Gottfredson, D. C. (1985). ''Victimization in schools''. New York: Plenum. {{ISBN|0-306-42023-6}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Johnson | first1 = S.L. | last2 = Burke | first2 = J.G. | last3 = Gielen | first3 = A.C. | year = 2011 | title = Prioritizing the school environment in school violence prevention efforts | url = | journal = Journal of School Health | volume = 81 | issue = 6| pages = 331–340 | pmid = 21592128 | doi = 10.1111/j.1746-1561.2011.00598.x | pmc = 4697272 }}</ref> Children in violent neighborhoods tend to perceive that their communities are risky, and that these feelings of vulnerability carry over to the school environment.<ref name="Tack 224–248">{{Cite journal|last=Tack|first=Anjanette M. Chan|date=February 2017|title=Making Friends in Violent Neighborhoods: Strategies among Elementary School Children|url=|journal=Sociological Science|volume=4|pages=224–248|via=}}</ref> Dilapidated housing in the neighbourhood of the school has been found to be associated with school violence.<ref name="limbos"/> Teacher assault was more likely to occur in schools located in high-crime neighbourhoods.<ref name="Casteel">{{cite journal | doi = 10.1002/ajim.20520 | last1 = Casteel | first1 = C. | last2 = Peek-Asa | first2 = C. | last3 = Limbos | first3 = M.A. | year = 2007 | title = Predictors of nonfatal assault injury to public school teachers in Los Angeles City | url = | journal = American Journal of Industrial Medicine | volume = 50 | issue = 12| pages = 932–939 | pmid = 17979131 }}</ref> Exposure to deviant peers is a risk factor for high levels of aggressivity.<ref name="akers"/><ref name="Loeber"/> Research has shown that [[poverty]] and high population densities are associated with higher rates of school violence.<ref name="Evans"/> Well controlled [[longitudinal study|longitudinal research]] indicates that children's exposure to community violence during the early elementary school years increases the risk of aggression later in elementary school, as reported by teachers and classmates.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1111/1467-8624.00623 | last1 = Guerra | first1 = N. G. | last2 = Huesmann | first2 = L. R. | last3 = Spindler | first3 = A. | year = 2003 | title = Community violence exposure, social cognition, and aggression among urban elementary school children | url = | journal = Child Development | volume = 74 | issue = 5| pages = 1561–1576 | pmid = 14552414 }}</ref> Other, well controlled longitudinal research that utilized [[propensity score matching]] indicates that exposure to gun violence in early adolescence is related to the initiation of serious physical violence in later adolescence.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1126/science.1110096 | last1 = Bingenheimer | first1 = J. B. | last2 = Brennan | first2 = R. T. | last3 = Earls | first3 = F. J. | year = 2005 | title = Firearm violence exposure and serious violent behavior | url = | journal = Science | volume = 308 | issue = 5726| pages = 1323–1326 | pmid = 15919997 }}</ref> Neighbourhood gangs are thought to contribute to dangerous school environments. Gangs use the social environment of the school to recruit members and interact with opposing groups, with gang violence carrying over from neighbourhoods into some schools.<ref>Wolfgang, M.E., Figlio, R.M., & Sellin, T. (1987). ''Delinquency in a birth cohort''. Chicago: University of Chicago Press. {{ISBN|0-226-90553-5}}</ref> Alternatively, many children who grow up in violent neighborhoods learn to deliberately find and make "street-oriented" friends as an instrumental tactic used to avoid being victimized.<ref name="Tack 224–248"/> Without the threat of violence, children more commonly develop friendships based on homophily, or shared traits.
===School environment=== Recent research has linked the school environment to school violence.<ref name="limbos"/><ref name="meyer">{{cite journal | last1 = Meyer-Adams | first1 = N. | last2 = Conner | first2 = B.T. | year = 2008 | title = School violence: Bullying behaviors and the psychosocial school environment in middle schools | url = http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_7200/is_200810/ai_n32297587/pg_9/ | journal = Children and Schools | volume = 30 | issue =4 | pages = 211–221 | doi=10.1093/cs/30.4.211}}{{dead link|date=August 2014}}</ref> Teacher assaults are associated with a higher percentage male faculty, a higher proportion of male students, and a higher proportion of students receiving free or reduced cost lunch (an indicator of poverty).<ref name="Casteel"/> In general, a large male population, higher grade levels, a history of high levels of disciplinary problems in the school, high student to [[teacher]] ratios, and an urban location are related to violence in schools.<ref name=limbos>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1111/j.1746-1561.2008.00341.x | last1 = Limbos | first1 = M.A.P. | last2 = Casteel | first2 = C. | year = 2008 | title = Schools and neighborhoods: Organizational and environmental factors associated with crime in secondary schools | url = | journal = Journal of School Health | volume = 78 | issue = 10| pages = 539–544 | pmid = 18808473 }}</ref><ref>Larsen, E. (2003). [http://www.eric.ed.gov/ERICDocs/data/ericdocs2sql/content_storage_01/0000019b/80/1b/99/86.pdf ''Violence in US public schools'']. ERIC Identifier: ED482921</ref> In students, academic performance is inversely related to antisocial conduct.<ref name = "Hirschi & Hindelang">{{cite journal | doi = 10.2307/2094556 | last1 = Hirschi | first1 = T. | last2 = Hindelang | first2 = M. J. | year = 1977 | title = Intelligence and delinquency: A revisionist review | jstor = 2094556| journal = American Sociological Review | volume = 42 | issue = 4| pages = 571–587 | pmid = 900659 }}</ref><ref name="CDC"/> The research by Hirschi<ref name="Hirschi"/> and others,<ref name="Sampson"/><ref name="Borowsky"/><ref name="Wiesner"/> cited above in the section on the home environment, is also consistent with the view that lack of attachment to school is associated with increased risk of antisocial conduct.
==Prevention and intervention== The goal of prevention and intervention strategies is to stop school violence from occurring. According to the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]], there are at least four levels at which violence-prevention programs can act: at the level of society in general, the school community, the family, and the individual.<ref>Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (2006). [https://www.cdc.gov/ncipc/duip/spotlite/SafeYouthSafeSchools.htm School health policies and programs study]. Retrieved on April 20, 2009.</ref>
*''Society-level prevention strategies'' aim to change social and cultural conditions in order to reduce violence regardless of where the violence occurs. Examples include reducing [[media violence research|media violence]], reshaping social [[norm (sociology)|norms]], and restructuring [[education|educational systems]].<ref name=CDC>Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.[https://www.cdc.gov/HealthyYouth/shpps/2006/factsheets/pdf/FS_ViolencePrevention_SHPP2006.pdf/ "School Health Policies and Programs Study 2006"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, 2008. Retrieved April 20, 2009.</ref> The strategies are rarely used and difficult to implement. **Now Is The Time is a federal initiative developed in 2013 in response to the growing number of gun related school violence incidents. The initiative will provide funding and resources to schools in an effort to reduce gun violence in schools. Funding will be provided for implementation of school interventions and training teachers and staff, programs that will support the mental and physical health of students, conflict resolution programs to reduce further school violence, and restoration of school environment after a violent incident.<ref>Examining School Safety and Gun Violence in America. (2014). Curriculum Review, 54(4), 8-9</ref> *''[[School Based Prevention Programs|School-wide strategies]]'' are designed to modify the school characteristics that are associated with violence. An avenue of [[Occupational health psychology#Workplace incivility and violence|psychological research]] is the reduction of violence and incivility, particularly the development of interventions at the level of the school.<ref name="Schon">Schonfeld, I.S. (2006). School violence. In E.K. Kelloway, J. Barling, & J.J. Hurrell, Jr. (Eds). [http://files.eric.ed.gov/fulltext/ED494566.pdf ''Handbook of workplace violence''] (pp. 169–229). Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage Publications.</ref><ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1016/S0962-1849(05)80077-0 | last1 = Howard | first1 = K. A. | last2 = Flora | first2 = J. | last3 = Griffin | first3 = M. | year = 1999 | title = Violence-prevention programs in schools: State of the science and implications for future research | url = | journal = Applied & Preventive Psychology | volume = 8 | issue = 3| pages = 197–215 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Scheckner | first1 = S. | last2 = Rollin | first2 = S. A. | last3 = Kaiser-Ulrey | first3 = Cheryl| last4 = Wagner | first4 = R. | year = 2002 | title = School Violence in children and adolescents: A meta-analysis of the effectiveness of current interventions | url = | journal = [[Journal of School Violence]] | volume = 1 | issue = 2 | pages = 5–32 | doi = 10.1300/J202v01n02_02 }}</ref> The CDC suggests schools promote classroom management techniques, [[cooperative learning]], and close student supervision.<ref name="CDC"/><ref>Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (2008). [https://www.cdc.gov/ncipc/dvp/CPTED.htm Using environmental design to prevent school violence]. Retrieved April 20, 2009.</ref> At the elementary school level, the group behavioral intervention known as the Good Behavior Game helps reduce classroom disruption and promotes prosocial classroom interactions.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1016/0193-3973(93)90013-L | last1 = Dolan | first1 = L. J. | last2 = Kellam | first2 = S. G. | last3 = Brown | first3 = C. H. | last4 = Werthamer-Larsson | first4 = L. | last5 = Rebok | first5 = G. W. | last6 = Mayer | first6 = L. W. |display-authors=etal | year = 1993 | title = The short-term impact of two classroom-based preventive interventions on aggressive and shy behaviors and poor achievement | url = | journal = Journal of Applied Developmental Psychology | volume = 14 | issue = 3| pages = 317–345 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1023/A:1020977107086 | last1 = Embry | first1 = D. D. | year = 2002 | title = The Good Behavior Game: A best practice candidate as a universal behavioral vaccine | url = | journal = Clinical Child and Family Psychology Review | volume = 5 | issue = 4| pages = 273–296 | pmid=12495270}}</ref> There is some evidence that the Second Step curriculum, which is concerned with promoting impulse control and empathy among second and third graders, produces reductions in physically aggressive behavior.<ref>{{cite journal|name-list-format=vanc| doi = 10.1001/jama.277.20.1605 | last1 = Grossman | first1 = D. C. | last2 = Neckerman | first2 = H. J. | last3 = Koepsell | first3 = T. D. | last4 = Liu | first4 = P. Y. | last5 = Asher | first5 = K. N. | last6 = Beland | first6 = K. | last7 = Frey | year = 1997 | first7 = K | last8 = Rivara | first8 = FP | title = Effectiveness of a violence prevention curriculum among children in elementary school: A randomized controlled trial | url = | journal = Journal of the American Medical Association | volume = 277 | issue = 20| pages = 1605–1611 | pmid = 9168290 }}</ref> Other school-wide strategies are aimed at reducing or eliminating bullying<ref>Olweus, D. (1991). Bully/victim problems among schoolchildren: Basic facts and effects of a school-based intervention. In D. Pepler & K. Rubin (Eds.), ''The development and treatment of childhood aggression'' (pp. 411–448). Hillsdale, NJ: Erlbaum.</ref><ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1111/j.1469-7610.1994.tb01229.x | last1 = Olweus | first1 = D. | year = 1994 | title = Annotation: Bullying at school: Basic facts and effects of a school-based intervention program | url = | journal = Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry, and Allied Disciplines | volume = 35 | issue = 7| pages = 1171–1190 | pmid = 7806605 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Olweus | first1 = D. | year = 1997 | title = Bully/victim problems in school: Knowledge base and an effective intervention program | url = | journal = Irish Journal of Psychology | volume = 18 | issue = | pages = 170–190 |issn=0303-3910 | doi=10.1080/03033910.1997.10558138}}; Also reprinted as {{cite journal | last1 = Olweus | first1 = DAN | title = Bullying at School: Knowledge Base and an Effective Intervention Program | journal = Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences | volume = 794 | pages = 265–276 | year = 1996 | doi = 10.1111/j.1749-6632.1996.tb32527.x }}</ref><ref>Olweus, D. (1999). The nature of school bullying: A cross-national perspective. In P. K. Smith, J. Junger-Taqs, D. Olweus, R. Catalano, & P. Slee (Eds.), ''The nature of school bullying: A cross-national perspective'' (pp. 7–27). New York: Plenum.</ref> and organizing the local police to better combat gang violence.<ref>Young, B. (2009, Mar. 2). [http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/cgi-bin/PrintStory.pl?document_id=2008800988&zsection_id=2003925728&slug=gangsandschools02m&date=20090302 Seattle schools scramble to outsmart gangs]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. ''Seattle Times''.</ref><ref>[http://talglobal.com/downloads/TAL_Global-CEB-Short_Case_Study.pdf TAL Global's CEB Case Study.]</ref> **The implementation of ''school-wide early-warning systems'', the school equivalent of a [[Distant Early Warning Line|DEW Line]]-like surveillance operation designed to "prevent the worst cases of school violence," has been problematic.<ref name="Schon"/> Recent developments in early threat assessment, however, show promise.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1080/15388220.2010.519432 | pmid = | title = Development, Evaluation, and Future Directions of the Virginia Student Threat Assessment Guidelines | year = 2011 | last1 = Cornell | first1 = Dewey | last2 = Allen | first2 = Korrie | journal = [[Journal of School Violence]] | volume = 10 | pages = 88–106 }}</ref> Violence-prevention efforts can also be usefully directed at developing anti-bullying programs, helping teachers with classroom-management strategies, applying behavioral strategies such as the Good Behavior Game, implementing curricular innovations such as the Second Step syllabus, developing programs to strengthen families (see below), and implementing programs aimed at enhancing the social and academic skills of at-risk students (see below). * Teachers are the professional group who works directly where school bullying takes place and who spends the most time with both bullies, victims and bystanders. Thus, whether and how teachers intervene in the case of bullying is of great importance. Research has shown that teachers prefer authority-based interventions towards bullies but seem to neglect to support the victims.<ref name="Burger 2015 191–202">{{cite journal| last = Burger| first = Christoph| last2 = Strohmeier| first2 = Dagmar| last3 = Spröber| first3 = Nina| last4 = Bauman| first4 = Sheri| last5 = Rigby| first5 = Ken| date = 2015| title = How teachers respond to school bullying: An examination of self-reported intervention strategy use, moderator effects, and concurrent use of multiple strategies.| url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.tate.2015.07.004| journal = Teaching and Teacher Education |volume=51| pages = 191–202| doi = 10.1016/j.tate.2015.07.004 }}</ref> Unfortunately, most teacher training curricula do not include preventive and interventive skills regarding school violence.<ref name="Burger 2015 191–202"/>
*Some intervention programs are aimed at ''improving family relationships''.<ref name="CDC"/> There is some evidence that such intervention strategies have modest effects on the behavior of children in the short<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1037/0022-006X.66.5.715 | last1 = Webster-Stratton | first1 = C. | year = 1998 | title = Preventing conduct problems in Head Start children: Strengthening parenting competencies | url = | journal = Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology | volume = 66 | issue = 5| pages = 715–730 | pmid = 9803690 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1037/0022-006X.63.4.560 | last1 = Tremblay | first1 = R. E. | last2 = Pagani-Kurtz | first2 = L. | last3 = Mâsse | first3 = L. C. | last4 = Vitaro | first4 = F. | last5 = Pihl | first5 = R. O. | year = 1995 | title = A bimodal preventive intervention for disruptive kindergarten boys: Its impact through mid-adolescence | url = | journal = Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology | volume = 63 | issue = 4| pages = 560–568 | pmid = 7673533 }}</ref> and long term.<ref>{{cite journal|name-list-format=vanc| doi = 10.1001/jama.280.14.1238 | last1 = Olds | first1 = D. | last2 = Henderson | first2 = C. R. Jr. | last3 = Cole | first3 = R. | last4 = Eckenrode | first4 = J. | last5 = Kitzman | first5 = H. | last6 = Luckey | first6 = D. | last7 = Pettitt | year = 1998 | first7 = L | last8 = Sidora | first8 = K | last9 = Morris | first9 = P | last10 = Powers | first10 = Jane | title = Long-term effects of nurse home visitation on children's criminal and antisocial behavior: 15-year follow-up of a randomized controlled trial | url = | journal = Journal of the American Medical Association | volume = 280 | issue = 14| pages = 1238–1244 | pmid = 9786373 | display-authors = 8 }}</ref> Patterson's home intervention program involving mothers has been shown to reduce aggressive conduct in children.<ref name="Patterson"/> An important question concerns the extent to which the influence of the program carries over into the child's conduct in school. *Some prevention and intervention programs focus on ''individual-level strategies''. These programs are aimed at students who exhibit [[aggression]] and violent behaviors or are at risk for engaging in such behaviors. Some programs include [[conflict resolution]] and team problem-solving.<ref name="CDC"/> Other programs teach students [[social skill]]s.<ref name="bennet">{{cite journal | last1 = Bennett-Johnson | first1 = E. | year = 2004 | title = The root of school violence: Causes and recommendations for a plan of action | url = http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0FCR/is_2_38/ai_n6130139 | journal = College Student Journal | volume = 38 | issue = | pages = 199–202 }}</ref> The Conduct Problems Prevention Research Group, while developing and implementing a universal anti-aggression component for all elementary school children, also developed and implemented a separate social-skills and academic tutoring component that targets children who are the most at risk for engaging in aggressive behavior.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1037/0022-006X.67.5.631 | last1 = Conduct Problems | first1 = Prevention Research Group | year = 1999a | title = Initial Impact of the Fast Track Prevention Trial for Conduct Problems: I. The High-Risk Sample | journal = Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology | volume = 67 | issue = 5| pages = 631–647 | pmid = 10535230 | pmc = 2762610 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1037/0022-006X.67.5.648 | last1 = Conduct Problems | first1 = Prevention Research Group | year = 1999b | title = Initial Impact of the Fast Track Prevention Trial for Conduct Problems: II. Classroom Effects | url = | journal = Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology | volume = 67 | issue = 5| pages = 648–657 | pmid = 10535231 | pmc = 2761630 }}</ref> * Bullying prevention programs such as Olweus provides materials for educators that will train them on how to mediate a bullying situation as well as procedures to take if a child is suicidal.
== Challenges in measuring violence in schools == Research on violence affecting children in schools is challenging for a variety of reasons.<ref name=":0" />
=== Methodological issues === When trying to measure the scope of violence in schools and to find out about the types of violence experienced by students, some key issues include: from what categories of the school community to collect the data; what data should be collected from each categories; and using which methods. For example, should there be studies or surveys where researchers ask students directly about violence in school, through self-reports about the violence they experienced as targets or perpetrators? Or should they be asked about incidents of violence that they have witnessed as bystanders? Should any of these questions be asked via self-administered questionnaires or questionnaires administered by researchers in schools? Does it make more sense to collect this data outside of schools, for example, through household surveys? Or through online surveys where students have access to the internet? Or is it better to rely on mechanisms for reporting incidents of violence in educational institutions when they are available, either in the schools themselves or outside schools (governmental hotlines, internet-based reporting systems, police and justice sectors, etc.)? What questions can be asked of children, using terminology that is easy to understand, age-appropriate and culturally sensitive?<ref name=":0" />
=== Legal and ethical issues === In most countries there are strict rules related to research involving children, as they are under the age of consent. Therefore, requesting informed consent from the children in a study involves their parents and guardians. Asking children about violence, and particularly violence they have experienced themselves, can be traumatic. Finally, researching [[Education and the LGBT community|issues related to sexual orientation and gender identity/orientation in education]] and in relation to children has additional challenges. In some contexts it is not legal to discuss these issues either in schools or even outside of schools. Where it is legal, it may be considered as a very sensitive topic to be discussed with children and young people. Asking children and young people questions related to their sexual orientation and gender identity in the school setting is ethically questionable, as it could embarrass them and expose them to stigma and discrimination, unless questions are asked in strict confidence and anonymity is granted by independent researchers external to schools.<ref name=":0" />

{{Expert needed|History of Science|ex2=Philosophy |reason= to take what is now a skeletal array of original research (editors here assigning events of which they are aware to the title category) and edit it into scholarly sourced content where published experts define, analyze, and provide examples of the important title subject; at the same time, settling on a standard format to citations, and moving the article toward that standard |date=May 2016}}
'''Self-experimentation''' refers to the special case of [[single-subject research]] in which the experimenter conducts the [[experiment]] on themself. Usually this means that a single person is the designer, operator, subject, analyst, and user or reporter of the experiment.
Current champions of self-experimentation include the late [[Seth Roberts]], [[Tim Ferriss]], and a sprawling community of [[Quantified Self]]
==Biology and medicine== {{main article|Self-experimentation in medicine}} {{expand section | actual content, from reliable sources, on the subject of the section title | small = no|date=April 2016}}
Human scientific self-experimentation principally (though not necessarily) falls into the fields of medicine and psychology. Self-experimentation has a long and well-documented history in medicine which continues to the present day.<ref>Who Goes First?: The Story of Self-Experimentation in Medicine by Lawrence Altman</ref>
For example, after failed attempts to infect piglets in 1984, [[Barry Marshall]] drank a [[petri dish]] of the [[Helicobacter pylori]] from a patient, and soon developed gastritis, [[achlorhydria]], stomach discomfort, nausea, vomiting, and [[halitosis]].<ref>{{cite news | title= Gut Instincts: A profile of Nobel laureate Barry Marshall| url=https://news.psu.edu/story/140921/2008/02/04/research/gut-instincts-profile-nobel-laureate-barry-marshall | author = Melissa Beattie-Moss | date=February 4, 2008 | journal= Penn State News}}</ref> The results were published in 1985 in the ''[[Medical Journal of Australia]],''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mja.com.au/ |title=Medical Journal of Australia |publisher=Mja.com.au |accessdate=2010-03-02}}</ref> and is among the most cited articles from the journal.<ref>{{cite journal | last =Van Der Weyden | first =Martin B | authorlink = |author2=Ruth M Armstrong |author3=Ann T Gregory | title =The 2005 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine | journal =[[Medical Journal of Australia]] | volume =183 | issue =11/12 | pages =612–614 | publisher =[[Australian Medical Association]] | year =2005 | url =http://www.mja.com.au/public/issues/183_11_051205/van11000_fm.html#0_i1091639 | accessdate = 2007-01-28 }}</ref> He was awarded the [[Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine]] in 2005.
Evaluations have been presented in the context of clinical trials and program evaluations.<ref>{{cite journal | title=Self experimenting doctors | journal= BMJ | date = 12 April 2011 | volume=342 | pages=d215 | doi= 10.1136/bmj.d2156 | author=Rebecca Ghani}}</ref><ref>David E.K. Hunter, "Daniel and the Rhinoceros", ''Evaluation and Program Planning'' Volume 29, Issue 2, May 2006, Pages 180-185 (Program Capacity and Sustainability). [https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.evalprogplan.2005.10.001]</ref>
==Psychology==
The self-experimental approach has long and often been applied to practical psychological problems. [[Benjamin Franklin]] recorded his self-experiment of successively devoting his attention for a week to one of thirteen "Virtues", "leaving the other Virtues to their ordinary Chance, only marking every Evening the Faults of the Day."<ref>{{cite book | title=The Autobiography of Benjamin Franklin | editor = Frank Woodworth Pine | date=1916 | url=https://excellence-in-literature.com/benjamin-franklin-13-virtues/}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Autobiography of Benjamin Franklin, Part 2 |url=http://www.ushistory.org/franklin/autobiography/page35.htm}}</ref>
In psychology, the best-known self-experiments are the memory studies of [[Hermann Ebbinghaus]], which established many basic characteristics of human memory through tedious experiments involving nonsense syllables.<ref>{{cite book|first=Hermann |last=Ebbinghaus |date=1913 |title=Über das Gedächtnis. Untersuchungen zur experimentellen Psychologie |publisher=NY Teachers College}}</ref>
In ''Self-change: Strategies for solving personal problems'', M. J. Mahoney suggested that self-experimentation be used as a method of psychological treatment, and recommended that clients be taught basic scientific methods, in order that the client become a "personal scientist."<ref>{{cite book | author= Mahoney, M. J. |date = 1979 | title=Self-change: Strategies for solving personal problems | publisher = New York: Norton}}</ref>
==Chemistry== {{refimprove section|date=April 2016}} Several popular and well-known sweeteners were discovered by deliberate or sometimes accidental tasting of reaction products. [[Sucralose]] was discovered by a scientist mishearing the instruction to "test" the compounds as to "taste" the compounds.<ref name="Gratzer2002">{{cite book|last=Gratzer|first=Walter |title=Eurekas and Euphorias: The Oxford Book of Scientific Anecdotes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4eTIxt6sN2oC&pg=PT32|accessdate=1 August 2012|date=28 November 2002|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-280403-7|pages=32–|chapter=5. Light on sweetness: the discovery of aspartame}}</ref> Fahlberg noticed a sweet taste on his fingers and associated the taste with his work in the chemistry labs at [[Johns Hopkins]]; out of that taste test came [[Saccharin]]. [[Cyclamate]] was discovered when a chemist noticed a sweet taste on his cigarette that he had set down on his bench. [[Aspartame]] was also discovered accidentally when chemist Schlatter tasted a sweet substance that had stuck to his hand. [[Acesulfame potassium]] is another sweetener discovered when a chemist tasted what he had made.
[[Leo Sternbach]], the inventor of [[Librium]] and [[Valium]], tested chemicals that he made on himself, saying in an interview, "I tried everything. Many drugs. Once, in the sixties, I was sent home for two days. It was an extremely potent drug, not a Benzedrine. I slept for a long time. My wife was very worried."<ref>"Little Helper", Nick Paumgarten, ''The New Yorker'', June 16, 2003, pp. 71-72. [http://www.newyorker.com/archive/2003/06/16/030616ta_talk_paumgarten]</ref>
Swiss chemist [[Albert Hofmann]] first discovered the [[psychedelic drug|psychedelic]] properties of [[LSD]] five years after its creation, when he [[History of lysergic acid diethylamide#Discovery|accidentally]] absorbed a small amount of the drug through his fingertips. Days later, he [[History of lysergic acid diethylamide#.22Bicycle Day.22|intentionally]] self-experimented with it.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Shroder|first1=Tom|title='Apparently Useless': The Accidental Discovery of LSD|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2014/09/the-accidental-discovery-of-lsd/379564/|publisher=The Atlantic|accessdate=7 December 2016}}</ref>
==Physics== [[Charles Dalziel]] studied the effects of electricity on animals and humans, and wrote ''The Effects of Electric Shock on Man'', a book in which he explains the effects of different amounts of electricity on human subjects.<ref>{{cite book|author=Dalziel, Charles F. |title=The effects of electric shock on man|publisher= Washington, D.C. : U.S. Atomic Energy Commission, Office of Health and Safety Series: Safety and fire protection technical bulletin; no. 7|year=1956}}</ref> He carried out experiments on human subjects, including himself. He also invented the [[ground-fault circuit interrupter]] or GFCI, based on his understanding of electric shock in humans.
In 1998 a British scientist, [[Kevin Warwick]], became the first human being to test an [[RFID]] as an implant to control surrounding technology.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/TECH/computing/9901/14/chipman.idg/|title= CNN story: Is human chip implant wave of the future? | date=1999-01-13}}</ref> In 2002 he went on to have an array of 100 electrodes fired into the [[median nerve]] of his left arm during a two-hour neurosurgical operation. With this implant in place, over a three-month period, he conducted a number of experiments, including the first direct electronic communication between the nervous systems of two humans.<ref>Warwick, K, Gasson, M, Hutt, B, Goodhew, I, Kyberd, P, Schulzrinne, H and Wu, X: "Thought Communication and Control: A First Step using Radiotelegraphy", IEE Proceedings on Communications, 151(3), pp.185-189, 2004</ref>
==Current practitioners of self experimentation==
The 21st century has seen a revival of self-experimentation. With the late [[Seth Roberts]] having a popular blog with many interesting findings of himself and others.<ref>{{ cite web | url=http://archives.sethroberts.net/blog/ | date= 13 Jan 2016 | title=Personal Science, Self-Experimentation, Scientific Method | author=Seth Roberts }}</ref> Bestselling author [[Tim Ferriss]] claims to be a self-experimenter to the extreme.<ref>{{cite web | title= The Value of Self-Experimentation | author=Tim Ferriss | url=https://tim.blog/2010/12/18/the-value-of-self-experimentation-plus-extreme-videos-do-not-try-this-at-home/}}</ref> The [[Quantified Self]] community has many members that do many kinds of experiments and meet-ups to report about them, along with yearly conferences discussing findings, methods and other aspects.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://quantifiedself.com/about/ | title=Quantified Self |access-date=20 Jul 2018}}</ref> [[Alexander Shulgin]] devoted his entire career to self experimentation, publishing his results in the widely acclaimed books [[PiHKAL]] and [[TiHKAL]]. Dr. Zee<ref>{{cite web |title=Dr Zee Home Page |url=https://www.drzee.org |website=Dr Zee |publisher=Dr Zee |accessdate=6 July 2018}}</ref>, a self-proclaimed Neo-Shulginist, is also known for a career of self experimentation<ref>{{cite news |last1=Jonze |first1=Tim |title=Dr Zee, the godfather of legal highs: I test everything on myself |url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/may/24/dr-zee-the-godfather-of-legal-highs-i-test-everything-on-myself |accessdate=6 July 2018 |publisher=The Guardian |date=24 May 2016}}</ref>.
==In fiction== {{unreferenced section|date=April 2016}} Examples in classic fiction include the tales of ''[[The Invisible Man]]'' and ''[[Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde]]''. In each case the scientist's unorthodox theories lead to permanent change and ultimately to self-destruction.
Self-experimentation is a common trait amongst [[mad scientist]]s and [[villain|evil genius]]es in more contemporary fiction and is part of the creation story of many [[comic book]] [[supervillain]]s, and some [[superhero]]es. For example, the [[Spider-Man]] villain [[Lizard (comics)|The Lizard]] lost his arm in a war (other versions vary), and experimented with reptilian DNA to try to grow it back; however, the therapy caused him to mutate into a half-human-half-reptile creature. The [[Fantastic Four]] were created when the Four were testing Reed Richards's new prototype rocket and were exposed to cosmic rays, giving them super powers. Other cases include the [[Man-Bat]], the [[Ultra-Humanite]], the [[Green Goblin]], and the [[Justice League (animated series)|animated Justice League]] version of [[Cheetah (comics)#Other media|Cheetah]].
The deepest example for self-experimentation was shown in [[Ang Lee]]'s ''[[Hulk (film)|Hulk]]'' (2003), where [[Brian Banner|David Banner]] experimented on himself to improve on his own limits, which is also why [[The Incredible Hulk|his son]] had many different abilities.

page.title: Taxation of the Jews in Europe

revision.text:
'''Taxation of the Jews in Europe''' refers to taxes imposed specifically on [[Jewish]] people in [[Europe]], in addition to the taxes levied on the general population. Special taxation imposed on the Jews by the state or ruler of the territory in which they were living has played an important part in Jewish history.<ref name="Judaica">[https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/History/ancienttaxation.html Taxation. Encyclopaedia Judaica.] Reproduced by Jewish Virtual Library.</ref> The abolition of special taxes on the Jews followed their admission to civil rights in France and elsewhere in Europe at the end of the 18th and beginning of the 19th centuries.<ref name="Judaica"/>
== In the Roman Empire == The [[Fiscus Judaicus]] ([[Latin]]: "Jewish tax") or "Temple Tax" was a [[tax]] collecting agency instituted to collect the tax imposed on [[Jewish diaspora#Post-Roman Diaspora|Jews]] in the [[Roman Empire]] after the destruction of the [[Second Temple|Temple of Jerusalem]] in 70 CE in favor of the temple of [[Temple of Jupiter Optimus Maximus|Jupiter Capitolinus]] in [[Ancient Rome|Rome]].
The tax was initially imposed by [[Roman Emperor]] [[Vespasian]] as one of the [[Anti-Judaism|measures against Jews]] as a result of the [[First Roman-Jewish War]] of 66–73 CE. Vespasian imposed the tax in the aftermath of the [[First Jewish–Roman War|Jewish revolt]] (Josephus ''BJ'' 7. 218; Dio Cassius 65.7.2). The tax was imposed on all Jews throughout the empire, not just on those who took part in the revolt against Rome. The tax was imposed after the [[destruction of the Second Temple]] in 70 CE in place of the levy (or [[Tithe]]) payable by Jews towards the upkeep of the Temple. The amount levied was two [[denarius|denarii]], equivalent to the one-half of a [[shekel]] that observant Jews had previously paid for the upkeep of the Temple of Jerusalem ({{bibleverse||Exodus|30:13|HE}}). The tax was to go instead to the [[Temple of Capitoline Jupiter]], the major center of [[Religion in ancient Rome|ancient Roman religion]]. The ''fiscus Iudaicus'' was a humiliation for the Jews.{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} In Rome, a special [[procurator (Roman)|procurator]] known as ''procurator ad capitularia Iudaeorum'' was responsible for the collection of the tax.<ref name="Fiscus">"Fiscus Judaicus", ''Encyclopedia Judaica''</ref> Only those who had abandoned Judaism were exempt from paying it.
== In the Holy Roman Empire == The Jewish populations of Europe were politically insecure and could be easily exploited for the levying of heavy taxes in exchange for official protection. The high interest rates charged by Jews became an illimitable source of tax revenue and Jewish wealth was technically easy to gauge because Jews typically stored their assets in the form of cash or promissory notes.<ref>{{cite book|author=Eberhard Isenmann|editor=Richard Bonney|title=The Rise of the Fiscal State in Europe c.1200-1815|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U24lRLy_qT8C&pg=PA259|date=2 September 1999|publisher=Clarendon Press|isbn=978-0-19-154220-6|pages=259–}}</ref>
The Imperial Tax Register of 1241 was the first register to include taxes on the Jews. The total of the taxes on the Jews listed in the Register amounted to 857 silver marks; the total contribution of all the cities together amounted to 4.290 silver marks. These local taxes served wholly or in part to finance town-building. Not all of the contributions reached the central administration. In contrast, it is clear from the Register that the payments made by the Jews reached the Exchequer in their entirety.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, pp. 13–14</ref> The taxes on the Jews were first described as the ’’Jewish Tax’’ in 1330.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, pp. 18–19</ref>
The Opferfennig (originally Guldenpfennig) tax was introduced in 1342 by Emperor [[Louis IV the Bavarian]], who ordered all Jews above the age of 12 and possessing 20 gulden to pay one gulden annually for protection. This taxation was 1 florin for every Jew and included assets worth more than 20 florins. Widows were not exempted. King Wenceslas removed the taxable minimum but an exemption for Jews dependent on alms was made later by Sigsmund, who himself levied heavy taxation. Sigsmund taxed a third of the value of Jewish properties. It was represented as a coronation tax as part of Sigsmund's attempts to ascend the throne. Isenmann disagrees and believes it was an innovation sprouted by Archchamberlain Konrad von Weinsberg. By 1433-4 the tax collectors were collecting tax worth a half of Jewish properties.<ref>{{cite book|author=Eberhard Isenmann|editor=Richard Bonney|title=The Rise of the Fiscal State in Europe c.1200-1815|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U24lRLy_qT8C&pg=PA259|date=2 September 1999|publisher=Clarendon Press|isbn=978-0-19-154220-6|pages=259–}}</ref>
Emperor [[Charles IV, Holy Roman Emperor|Charles IV]] later ordered the income of the Opferfennig tax to be delivered to the archbishop of [[Triers]]. This tax was at some places replaced by an overall communal tax.<ref>[http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/judaica/ejud_0002_0015_0_15120.html OPFERPFENNIG. Encyclopaedia Judaica]. 2008.</ref>
== Leibzoll ==
The ''[[Leibzoll]]'' or ''Judengeleit'' was a special [[tariff|toll]] which Jews had to pay in most of the European states in the [[Middle Ages]] and up to the beginning of the nineteenth century.<ref>{{Cite book| author=Isidore Singer, Cyrus Adler | title=The Jewish Encyclopedia, Vol. 7 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SzsyAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA669| year=1906| publisher=Funk & Wagnalls Company|page=669}}</ref>
== In Hungary == [[Tolerance tax]] (Toleranzgebührer) was a [[tax]] that was levied against [[Jews]] of [[Hungary]], then part of the [[Austrian Empire]], beginning in 1747.<ref name="jg">JewishGen. Hungary: Assorted Census Records, 1781-1850 [database on-line]. Provo, UT, USA: The Generations Network, Inc., 2008.</ref>
The tax was based on the German statute that a Jew was obliged to pay a certain tax to be "tolerated".<ref>Wine and thorns in Tokay Valley: Jewish life in Hungary : the history of Abaújszántó, by Zahava Szász Stessel, Fairleigh Dickinson Univ Press, 1995, p. 50-51</ref>
== In Poland ==
=== Koło === In 1571 a contract was drafted with regard to the status of the Jews in [[Koło]], in which the city's Christians have undertaken to provide protection to the Jews, in return for which the Jews were required to pay a special annual municipal tax.<ref name="mahler">Mahler, Rafael. [http://www.jewishgen.org/yizkor/kolo/kol008.html "From the near and far past". Some information about the history of the Jews of Koło.]</ref>
In 1729 the Jewish community was required to pay 150 gold coins as an annual poll tax, and in 1738 this sum was increased to 300 gold coins.<ref name="mahler"/>
In 1775 the Polish parliament imposed a special duty on books written in [[Hebrew]] and [[Yiddish]], requiring each book to be stamped by the municipality. Despite heavy penalties imposed on owners of unstamped books, many books were concealed and unstamped.<ref name="mahler"/>
== In Russia == The Russian [[Kosher tax]], known as the ''korobka'', was a tax paid only by Jews for each animal slaughtered in accordance with the [[kashrut]] rules and for each pound of this meat sold.<ref name="ji"/><ref>[http://www.shtetlinks.jewishgen.org/kraziai/history_tax_on_jews.htm Korobka Tax on Kraziai's Jews], Document 49-1-1362 from the Kaunas Archive</ref> It was part of the Russian Jewish "basket tax" or "box tax". Though it was used to refer to a tax on meat or slaughtering, the word ''korobka'' (Russian: коробка) actually means "box" in Russian. The tax came to be called that because Jews paying had to deposit a coin in a box at the kosher slaughterer.<ref name=Diner2001p164>[[Hasia R. Diner|Diner, Hasia R.]] ''Hungering for America: Italian, Irish, and Jewish Foodways in the Age of Migration'', [[Harvard University Press]], 2001, {{ISBN|978-0-674-00605-8}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=zU1WYFWxn74C&pg=PA164 p. 164.]</ref>
According to [[Herman Rosenthal]] and [[Jacob Goodale Lipman]], the tax was "the most burdensome and annoying of the special taxes imposed upon the Jews of Russia by the government".<ref name="ji">[[Herman Rosenthal|Rosenthal, Herman]]; [[Jacob Goodale Lipman|Lipman, J.G.]] [http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/view.jsp?artid=394&letter=B "Basket-Tax"], ''[[Jewish Encyclopedia]]''.</ref><ref name="Belovinskiĭ2003p357">Leonid Vasilʹevich Belovinskiĭ. ''Энциклопедический словарь российской жизни и истории: XVIII-начало XX в'', Olma Media Group, 2003, {{ISBN|978-5-224-04008-7}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=4W5sUATx57MC&pg=PA357 p. 357.]</ref><ref>[[Simon Dubnow|Dubnow, Simon]]; [[Israel Friedlander|Friedlaender, Israel]]. ''History of the Jews in Russia and Poland'', Avotaynu Inc, 2000 {{ISBN|978-1-886223-11-0}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=vL60sEf7OPoC&pg=PA227&lpg=PA227 p. 227.]</ref> The burden of taxes, and the ''korobka'' in particular, was one of the factors which drove many Jews to abandon the towns and settle in villages or on noblemen estates.<ref>Encyclopaedia Judaica (1971): History, vol. 8, 734</ref>
==In Galicia== Between 1777 and 1784, the Jews of [[Horodenka]], a region on the southeast corner of [[Galicia (eastern Europe)|Galicia]], paid a number of special taxes, including the "protection and [[tolerance tax]]", and the "property and occupation tax". In 1784, the property and occupation tax was replaced with the kosher meat tax.<ref>Gelber, N. M. ''The History of the Jews of Horodenka'', p. 86.</ref>
==In Moldavia== In 1741, Moldavian prince [[Grigore II Ghica|Grigore Ghica]] confirmed the obligation of each Jew to pay the crupca, an indirect tax on kosher meat similar to the Russian ''korobka''.<ref>[http://www.yivoencyclopedia.org/printarticle.aspx?id=925 Iaşi, by Lucian-Zeev Herşcovici ]</ref>
== In Altona and Hamburg == During the period 1641–1842, the [[Jews]] of [[Altona, Hamburg|Altona]] (then a town close to Hamburg) paid specifically Jewish taxes as well as the same taxes as other residents of Altona. The tax burden on the members of the Jewish community was twice as heavy as that on the other residents.
In 1640 the Danish King [[Christian IV]] acquired part of the [[Holstein-Pinneberg|County of Pinneberg]] including Altona.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, pp. 25–26</ref> Altona was subsequently granted the rights and status of a town on 23 August 1664.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, pp. 53–54</ref>
=== Jews in Hamburg ===
The community was founded principally by Portuguese merchants and was known as the [[Portuguese Jewish community in Hamburg|Portuguese-Jewish Community]], although many of its members were of Spanish-Jewish descent.
These [[Sephardic Jews]], who initially pretended to be persecuted [[Catholic]]s, first came to [[Hamburg]] at the end of the 16th century. They were mostly Portuguese- or Spanish-speaking merchants. In 1621, when the armistice between [[Spain]] and the [[Netherlands]] came to an end, many of the Portuguese Jews moved to Hamburg. They were made welcome, even after the actual situation had become clear; however they were not permitted to establish a cemetery within the city walls. Thanks to the linguistic skills of the Sephardim and their contacts among their co-religionaries they controlled a large sector of the German market in provisions. The Sephardim differed culturally and socially from the Jews who came to Altona, and subsequently also to Hamburg, from the east. These were [[Yiddish Language]] speaking [[Ashkenazim]]. The permanent settlement of the Ashkenazim was opposed by both the [[Senate of Hamburg]] (town council) and the citizens, supported by the Sephardim, who did not wish to see the establishment of a second community in Hamburg. As servants, referred to as tudescos, the Ashkenazi Jews were, de facto, under the protection of the Sephardic Jews.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, pp. 91–94</ref>
=== Jews in Altona ===
On 1 August 1641 the Danish king had formally granted the Ashkenazi Jews the privilege of having in Altona, as hitherto, a cemetery and a synagogue, thus providing the basis for the existence of a Jewish community.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, p. 111</ref> Subsequently, the Danish kings promised the Jews personal security, the freedom to practice trade and religious liberties. Some of the Jews living in Hamburg therefore tried to secure the legal protection of the Danish crown in case of any attempt to expel them. In Altona the conditions of residence were favorable, in Hamburg the conditions for trading. These were the reasons for the genesis of the Altona community of Ashkenazi Jews from Hamburg and Altona.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, p. 91</ref> Thanks to immigration from the east, Altona became a center of research and scholarship in Jewish teaching, attracting hundreds of students. The officially recognized [[Beth din|Jewish court of justice]] had a reputation as one of the most distinguished in the whole Jewish world.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, pp. 243–244</ref> The Jews did not acquire these privileges freely, but in return for the payment of taxes.
=== Levies on Jews ===
From 1584 to 1639, as in the Middle Ages, the Jews of Altona paid taxes specific to the Jews, but no further taxes. Each Jewish family was required to pay 6 [[rixdollar|Reichstaler]] per year. Under Danish rule this changed: the Jews continued to pay the specifically Jewish taxes plus the same taxes as all other residents.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, p. 135</ref> From 1641 every Jewish family was required to pay 5 Reichstaler in Jewish taxes; in the year when Altona became a town the contribution rose to 6 Reichstaler.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, p. 135, pp. 180–181</ref> With the ordinance of 1641 the Danish king had permitted the Jews [[shechita]]. This privilege too was not cost-free. For the years 1667–1669 we have records of taxes paid by Jewish butchers. According to these the rates were 1 Mark and 8 Schillinge for an ox, 4 Schillinge for a calf and 2 Schillinge for a lamb. These taxes were twice as high as those paid by Christian butchers.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, p. 153, pp. 168–169</ref> From 1681 Individual taxes on the Jews (6 Reichstaler plus the payments made by the Jewish butchers), were replaced by lump-sum payments by the Jewish community.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, p. 156</ref>
From the year 1712 onwards it is possible to calculate the amount of the lump-sum payments made by the Jews. During the period 1712–1818 this amounted to 6 Reichstaler for each Jewish family; 6 Reichstaler was the level that had already been set in 1584. Assuming that a Jewish family consisted of approximately 6 persons, 6 Reichstaler corresponded to 1 Reichstaler for each individual Jew. On top of this 1 Reichstaler, also paid by the other residents, had to be paid.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, pp. 265-266. Meaningful conversion of the face-value can be made for this period since, unlike the paper money of Copenhagen, the silver currency of Altona was stable, p. 50</ref> The tax burden on the members of the Jewish community was twice as heavy as that on the other residents. The influence of this on business practice constituted an obstacle to the granting of civil rights. In the year 1818 the Jewish Elders declared to the community of Altona that they could not, ’’on the one hand, levy specifically Jewish taxes on the members of their community and, on the other hand, encourage our co-religionaries, especially the younger ones, to pursue useful activity. In short: so to improve our condition that we might not seem unworthy to acquire civil rights. The extension – against our wishes - of the taxes on the Jews would be incompatible with the granting of civil rights.’’<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, p. 239</ref> This marks the beginning of the struggle of the Jewish community for emancipation. The Jewish community secured the abolition of taxes on the Jews in the year 1842.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, p. 199</ref>

'''The Pacific Identity and Wellbeing Scale (PIWBS)''' is a [[self-report inventory]] with a [[Likert scale]] format, designed to assess five distinct dimensions of [[Personal identity|identity]] and [[subjective well-being]] among Pacific populations in [[New Zealand]]: # Group Membership Evaluation # Pacific Connectedness and Belonging # Religious Centrality and Embeddedness # Perceived Familial Wellbeing # Perceived Societal Wellbeing
The PIWBS was developed by Sam Manuela, a doctoral candidate at [[The University of Auckland]].<ref>Manuela, S. (2010). The Pacific Identity and Wellbeing Scale. Published master’s thesis. The University of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand.</ref><ref>Manuela, S. & Sibley, C. G. (2012). The Pacific Identity and Wellbeing Scale (PIWBS): A Culturally-Appropriate Self Report Measure for Pacific Peoples in New Zealand. Social Indicators Research, 1, 83-103.</ref><ref>Manuela, S. & Sibley, C. G (2012). Why Do Pacific People with Multiple Ethnic Affiliations Have Poorer Subjective Wellbeing? Negative Ingroup Affect Mediates the Identity Tension Effect. Social Indicators Research, 1, 1-18.</ref> The scale aims to provide a culturally sensitive, valid and reliable [[self-report inventory]] of Pacific identity and [[subjective well-being]] which aids the understanding and predicting of Pacific outcomes. The measure contributes to Pacific studies by providing a [[quantitative research|quantitative]], within-cultural research tool for Pacific peoples from a Pacific perspective. The PIWBS is associated with the [[New Zealand Attitudes and Values Study]].
The dimensions, Group Membership Evaluation, Pacific Connectedness and Belonging, and Religious Centrality and Embeddness all relate to identity. Answers to questions relating to identity are rated on a [[Likert scale]] ranging from 1 to 7 (1 = strongly disagree and 7 = strongly agree). The dimensions, Perceived Familial Wellbeing and Perceived Societal Wellbeing both relate to wellbeing. Answers to questions relating to [[wellbeing]] are rated on a [[Likert scale]] ranging from 1 to 7 (1 = completely dissatisfied and 7 = completely satisfied).
==The Five Dimensions==
===1. Group Membership Evaluation (GME)===
This factor reflects subjective evaluations of membership within the Pacific group. Positive group evaluations are shown through pride in one's [[ethnic identity]] and [[culture]],<ref>Mila-Schaaf, K., Robinson, E., Schaaf, D., Denny, S., & Watson, P. D. (2008). A health profile of Pacific youth: Findings of youth 2000. A National Secondary School Youth Health Survey. Auckland: University of Auckland.</ref> and represent a secure ethnic identity.<ref>Anae, M. (1998). Fofoa-i-vao-’ese: The identity journeys of NZ-born Samoans. Unpublished doctoral dissertation, University of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand.</ref> This factor includes an evaluation of positive effect brought about by Pacific group membership, and an evaluation of the extent to which one's Pacific identity is seen as a central and defining aspect of [[self-concept]]. High scores on this factor would indicate that positive/worthwhile feelings are derived from Pacific identification, and that affiliation with a Pacific group is seen as a desirable aspect of self-concept and is central to identity.
====Sample Group Membership Evaluation Items====
* The fact that I am an Islander is an important part of my identity * Being an Islander is an important part of how I see myself * I am glad to be a Pacific Islander * I am proud to be a Pacific Islander * Being a Pacific Islander gives me a good feeling
====2. Pacific Connectedness and Belonging (PCB)==== This factor is a measure of an individual's sense of [[belongingness|belonging]] and connectedness with Pacific others and groups. These feelings derive from shared experiences and commonalities and are particularly apparent among youth,.<ref>Macpherson, C. (1996). Pacific Islands identity and community. In P. Spoonley, D. Pearson, & C. Macpherson (Eds.), Nga Patai: Racism and ethnic relations in Aotearoa/New Zealand (pp. 124–143). Palmerston North, NZ: Dunmore Press.</ref><ref>Anae, M. (1998). Fofoa-i-vao-’ese: The identity journeys of NZ-born Samoans. Unpublished doctoral dissertation, University of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand.</ref><ref>Tiatia, J. (1998). Caught between cultures: A New Zealand-born Pacific Island perspective. Auckland: Christian Research Association.</ref> This factor, which assesses the extent to which the individual believes the self to be an integral part of a Pacific group, is made up of two distinct dimensions. The first dimension concerns perceived connections/relationships with others, and the second dimension concerns an individual's subjective sense of belonging at a broader level. High scores on this factor would indicate that the individual feels similar to Pacific others, and perceives themselves to be an integral member of the wider, general group, and have a feeling of belonging.
=====Sample Pacific Connectedness and Belonging Items===== * I feel at home around other Islanders, even if they are not from my Island * I feel comfortable in places with lots of other Pacific peoples * I don’t get along with other island groups (reverse coded) * I feel connected to other Pacific peoples in general * I feel connected to people from a different Pacific Island to myself * I feel most comfortable in Pacific communities
====3. Religious Centrality and Embeddedness (RCE)==== This factor assesses the individual's evaluation of the extent to which [[religion]] is central to their identity as Pacific, and the extent to which they believe religion to be entwined with Pacific [[culture]]. [[Religion]] is an important aspect of Pacific identity, having a huge influence on many Pacific communities by providing social connections and support, and fulfilling cultural and religious needs.<ref>Anae, M. (2001). The New Vikings of the sunrise: New Zealand-born in the information age. In P. Spoonley, C. Macpherson, & M. Anae (Eds.), Tagata o te Moana Nui: The evolving identities of Pacific peoples in Aotearoa, New Zealand (pp. 89–101). Palmerston North, NZ: Dunmore Press.</ref><ref>Tiatia, J. (1998). Caught between cultures: A New Zealand-born Pacific Island perspective. Ellerslie, Auckland: Christian Research Association.</ref> This factor focuses on [[Christianity]]-based religions which are the most common in Pacific societies. High scores on this factor would indicate that the individual feels that [[Christianity]]-based religion is a central aspect of self-identity, and is strongly linked to their Pacific [[culture]].
=====Sample Religious Centrality and Embeddedness Items===== * Going to Church is part of my culture and religion * God has a strong connection to my culture * Religion is not important for my culture (reverse coded) * Part of being a Pacific Islander is having a connection with God * Religion is the root of our Pasifika culture * Our religion is the centre of our culture as Pacific Islanders
====4. Perceived Familial Wellbeing (PFW)==== This factor assesses the individual's subjective satisfaction with their family, and the [[subjective well-being]] of and within their family. Family offers [[Human body|physical]], mental, [[cultural]], [[spirituality|spiritual]] and [[social]] nurturance, and is an integral aspect of Pacific [[self-concept]], closely tied to wellbeing.<ref>Tamasese, K., Peteru, C., & Waldegrave, C. (1997). O le Taeo Afua—The new morning: A qualitative investigation into Samoan perspectives on mental health and culturally appropriate services. Wellington: The Family Centre & NZ Health Research Council.</ref> This factor assesses a variety of Pacific family values including [[respect]], [[communication]], [[Interpersonal relationship|relationships]] and [[happiness]]. High scores in this factor would indicate that the individual feels a strong sense of [[social support|support]] from their family, and that the individual perceives their family as a whole to have a high level of wellbeing.
=====Sample Perceived Familial Wellbeing Items===== * Your relationship with your parents * Your family's security * The respect you give for your parents * The respect you receive from your family * Your position in your family * Your family's happiness * Communication with your family
====5. Perceived Societal Wellbeing (PSW)==== This factor reflects the individual's [[Contentment|satisfaction]] with [[society]] and the [[social support|support]] it offers. Satisfaction with society has a strong influence on the subjective wellbeing of Pacific people.<ref>Ministry of Health. (1995). Pacific Islands peoples’ understanding of mental health. Strategic directions for the mental health services for Pacific Islands people. Wellington: Ministry of Health.</ref><ref>Kupa, K. (2009). Te Vaka Atafaga: a Tokelau assessment model for supporting holistic mental health practice with Tokelau people in Aotearoa, New Zealand. Pacific Health Dialog, 15, 156–163.</ref> Perceived support from society is assessed on various levels, from the local community level to the national government level and responses indicate how supported and integrated the Pacific individual feels in New Zealand. High scores on this factor would indicate that the individual feels satisfied, supported and accepted by all levels of New Zealand society.
=====Sample Perceived Societal Wellbeing Items===== * Support provided to you by the New Zealand government to you as a Pacific Islander * Your position in New Zealand as a Pacific person * Your personal needs being met by New Zealand * The support you receive as a Pacific Islander in the community you live in * Your relationship with New Zealand society * The support you receive in the community you live in * The support you receive as a Pacific Islander in New Zealand
==Validation of the PIWBS==
The Pacific Identity and Wellbeing Scale was developed and validated using [[exploratory factor analysis]] (EFA) and [[confirmatory factor analysis]] (CFA). The initial pool of 125 questions was developed based on previous Pacific research, a variety of other wellbeing and identity scales, discussions with Pacific peoples and the [[Multi-dimensional Model of Maori Identity and Cultural Engagement]].<ref>Houkamau, C. A., & Sibley, C. G. (2010). The multi-dimensional model of Maori identity and cultural engagement. New Zealand Journal of Psychology, 39, 8–25.</ref>
[[Exploratory factor analysis]] (EFA) was conducted to organise the 125 possible questions into groups (factors) based on similarity of topic. Individual items that did not fit a group well or that related to more than one group were not used. Thirty-one questions were retained which were found to measure the five distinct, yet interconnected factors of Pacific identity and wellbeing. [[Confirmatory factor analysis]] (CFA) was later used to confirm the structure of the PIWBS. All 31 items were found to be strongly related to the predicted factors. [[Cronbach's alpha]] (internal reliability) measures the extent to which all the questions in a section measure the same construct/factor consistently. The five factors of the PIWBS showed excellent internal reliability, with [[Cronbach's alpha]]s all above α = 0.85. The minimum accepted standard of internal reliability is α = 0.70.
The PIWBS has been used in several studies to investigate the low levels of [[subjective well-being]] found among Pacific peoples who identify with multiple [[ethnic group]]s.<ref>Manuela, S. & Sibley, C. G (2012). Why Do Pacific People with Multiple Ethnic Affiliations Have Poorer Subjective Wellbeing? Negative Ingroup Affect Mediates the Identity Tension Effect. Social Indicators Research, 1, 1-18.</ref> Differences were found in levels of [[subjective well-being]] depending on the number of ethnic groups the individual associated with. For example, people who identified only as Pacific had higher levels of wellbeing than people who identified as both Pacific and non-Pacific (e.g. New Zealand European). However, there were no differences in wellbeing levels between people who identified as only Pacific, and people who identified with two Pacific groups (e.g. [[Tongans|Tongan]] and [[Samoans|Samoan]]). This suggests that lower wellbeing only occurred when the two [[ethnic group]]s associated with, were very different (e.g. Pacific and New Zealand European).
Identity Tension Effect: Associating with both a Pacific group and a majority ethnic group (e.g. [[New Zealand European]]) may lead to negative feelings about Pacific aspects of [[Personal identity|identity]]. This is because people who identify with multiple [[ethnic group]]s tend to be more likely to [[internalise]] negative [[stereotypes]] about Pacific people held by the majority. This can lead to identity confusion and lowered [[self-esteem]].
[[Population projection]]s suggest that the Pacific community will grow by 60% by 2026.<ref>Ministry of Social Development. (2008). Diverse communities: Exploring the refugee and migrant experience in New Zealand. Wellington, NZ: Ministry of Social Development.</ref> Approximately one third of Pacific people identify as both Pacific and non-Pacific. This means that a growing percentage of the New Zealand population may be at risk of a number of negative outcomes. These outcomes include both lower [[self-esteem]], as well as decreased feelings of support from family. Through applied research interventions such as challenging negative [[stereotype]]s and promoting positive [[stereotype]]s about Pacific peoples, it may be possible to address this problem.

(1998). Fofoa-i-vao-’ese : the identity journeys of NZ-born Samoans (Thesis)]
